text: The colored shapes dart around the screen -- the impressi of looking through a kaleidoscope. As the image comes into sharp focus, we discover that we inside a CANDY BOWL.  A MAN'S FINGERS are frantically removing all the cherry-flavored pieces of candy.

The man performing this curious task is writer/producer/director, VIKTOR TARANSKY, forties, conservatively dressed in suit and tie.  He sits alone at empty craft service table outside a cavernous soundstage, some distance from the rest of the film set -- a breeze b the table's paper cloth. Viktor finishes sorting.  Finding no trash can to deposit rejected cherry candy, he scoops them into his pocket. A young headset-clad P.A. hurriedly approaches.  He looks ill.
Mr. Taransky --
Viktor reads the young P.A.'s panicked expression.
She's walking?... Don't tell me she's walking. (blood slowly draining from his face) She is not walking... She can't walk.
NICOLA ANDERS, twenty-something, A-list actress, beautifu face scowling, is supervising her ASSISTANT ferrying clot from a movie trailer to a limousine.  VIKTOR desperately follows after Nicola.
-- Nicola!  How was your massage?
You're in breach.
-- Is this about the new pages? -- I made the changes you wanted, you're in virtually every scene --
(wheeling on him) It's not the size of the role, Viktor. (suddenly very cool) Am I or am I not contractually entitled to the biggest trailer on the set?
(regarding the enormous silver fish behind them, confused) It's the biggest on earth!  I swear!  It's a 50-foot Airstream -- they don't make them any longer than that.
Taller, Viktor.
Taller?  What?
Viktor looks up in horror.  The trailer next to Nicola's indeed appear to be fractionally taller.
(walking away) You've insulted me for the last time.
Viktor looks to the tires.  His face suddenly brightens.
Nicola, it's just the tires -- they're over-inflated!  I can fix it!
Viktor grasps the air nozzle on a tire and begins despera stabbing at it with a ballpoint pen.  Air hisses out.
See, it's lower already.
Nicola ignores Viktor, marching towards her limo with her PUBLICIST.  Abandoning the trailer, Viktor hurries after
I beg you.  You can't do this to me.
(looking back) I had three other offers.  I only signed on to this picture out of... loyalty.
Then show some.  They'll shut me down!

(opening the car door) It wasn't working anyhow.  The scene with the thousand geese -- I don't understand this film.  I don't think anyone will understand it.  I already put out a press release -- citing "creative differences".
Viktor stops, nods resignedly -- suddenly very calm.

You know what, Nicola, you're right. (picking up her last piece of luggage) Here, let me help you with that. (holding the door for her) You ought to go.  The truth is I don't deserve you.  This film doesn't deserve you.  Frankly, it deserves much, much better.  The reason it's not working is because you're not about the work.
Nicola is stunned.
(to the limo driver) To Hell, please.
The door slams and the limo roars away.  Viktor looks to still hissing trailer tire.  The CREW regards Viktor apprehensively.
(to the crew) What are you looking at?  Get back to work.
The crew is uncertain what work there is to do.
In an ornate bedroom, NICOLA lies on her death bed under veil of netting.  A distraught man, HAL, sits close by.
(whispered) Jack... are you there?
I'm here.  I'm right beside you.
A NUN enters.
(to Hal) You should really go now.
No, it's alright.  Please, let him stay.
The nun withdraws.  Hal holds his face in his hands, almo breaking down.
(a glance to heaven) What kind of cruel God is it that would take you away from me?
The same one who brought me to you.
No... I cannot accept it.  If something like this can happen.  What... (struggling to find the words) What is it for?
(smiles through her pain) -- Why are we here?  Is that what you're asking, Jack?... Why are we here?  No why.  Just here.
Nicola dies peacefully.

VIKTOR sits with leading man HAL, THREE EXECUTIVES and st head ELAINE CHRISTIAN, watching a rough assembly of the f It ends with a close up of NICOLA ANDERS. The lights go up.  The image of Nicola fades off the scre
She's good.  You can hardly tell she's reading off a teleprompter.
(ignoring him) I've analyzed the footage.  We've got almost everything we need in the can.  If we rework the script, we can finish the film without her.
(forceful shake of the head) According to the writ her attorneys filed at noon today.  They'll sue if the film is released with Nicola in a single frame.
(more anxious) So we'll re-cast.
Nicola Anders is the only actress who can play that role.
(incredulous) It's a re-make, Hal.  Anders is not bigger than this picture.
Elaine finally speaks up.
Of course she is.  No other name is going to sign on now and risk offending her.
We don't need a name.  We'll cast an unknown.
I won't play opposite an unknown.
We can't sell an unknown.  Nicola's soured on the project and we have to accept that.  If we ever want to be in the Nicola Anders business again, we have to cut our losses and shelve the picture.
The executives, leading man and director nod sagely.
(aghast) No!  You will not give in to that blackmailing bitch!
(a wince, addressing everyone but Viktor) Excuse us.
Elaine ushers Viktor out of the screening room.
ELAINE and VIKTOR talk in the shadow of an enormous soundstage.  They speak more freely in each other's compa
God, Viktor.  Why do you always have to make things so difficult for yourself?
Difficult.  I'm difficult.
He produces a handful of candy from his pocket.
(referring to the candy) -- Do you know what these are, Elaine?
(talking a piece of candy and eating it) Hmm... Mike and Ike's.
Not just any Mike & Ike's -- cherry Mike & Ike's.  Do you know why I, Viktor Taransky, two-time Academy Award nominated director --
-- Viktor, that was Short Subject.
-- overseeing the most cherished movie project of my career, am walking around with a pocketful of cherry Mike & Ike's?
Elaine takes a seat in a nearby studio cart as Viktor pac
-- I have a feeling you're going to tell me.

-- I'll tell you why.  It is because Miss Nicola Anders, supermodel with a SAG card God's gift to cinema, has it written into her contract that all cherry Mike & Ike's be removed from her candy dish along with strict instructions that any room she walks into should have seven packs of cigarettes waiting for her three of them opened, that there be a personal jacuzzi within eighty paces of her dressing room, and that any time she travels, her nanny must fly with her first class.
-- What's wrong with that?
Elaine, she doesn't have any children! (grabbing her arm) Don't you see?  We're being held hostage by 12 men and 5 women who someone somewhere has decreed are the A-list.
The public decides who's on that list.
Please.
It's the truth.  Those 17 superstars are our insurance policy.  We can't open -- can't make a profit without them.

We can hardly make a profit with them.  Up-front salary, back-end deal, perks, per diem, percentages  -- They're mocking us, Elaine.  We're at their mercy. (staring wistful, into space) We always had movie stars but they used to be our stars.  We used to decide who would play what role.  We told them what to wear, what to say, who to date.  When they were under contract, we could change their names if we wanted to -- more than once!
(regarding him as if he's insane) You realize you're nostalgic for an era you weren't even born in?

(irritated at her infuriating logic) Well, I do remember why I started out in this business -- you seem to have forgotten -- working in New York with Cassevetes -- we were trying to do something important, shine a light in that darkened cinema --
(rolling her eyes) -- It's called a projector.
(ignoring her) -- Illuminate hearts and minds with a ray of truth.
Listen, Viktor, I have good memories of those days too -- but this isn't about that or you or me or some high-minded ideal.  This is business.
Spare me.
(gesturing at the studio lot) -- Christ, Viktor, look around.  What do you think pays for all this?  This is about investment and return.  Those days in New York... that's... it's over.
A pause.  Viktor reads Elaine's face.
You're not renewing my contract.
How can I?  Your last three pictures tanked.  The board is giving me hell.  No bankable star will work with you after this.  If you just compromised... a little.
Viktor eats some of the candy in his hand as he takes in news.
(rueful smile) -- Well, it's not every day you're fired by the mother of your own child.
Elaine also eats some more candy -- a curiously intimate moment between them.

(softening, a heart-to heart) I'm not taking away your daughter, just your deal.  You and I both know, after the divorce I kept you on for old time's sake, so you could still hold your head up in front of Lainey.  I called what's his name at Warner's.  He said he'd take a meeting -- in July.  I've fought for you Viktor... (voice trails off) You want to talk severance?
(staring off into the distance, face hardening) You can have everything -- office, car, assistants -- all I want is the picture.
(confused) The picture's dead.
So there's no problem -- I can have the rights, the negative too?
(believing she's getting off lightly) They're yours.  But how are you going to finish it?  Without a star there's no movie.
I don't need a star.  All I need is an actor -- I'll reshoot the part, cut out Nicola and replace her with a real actor.  A real leading lady.

Even if you find her, you know the problem with unknowns, Viktor.  If they're good, they get known.  And then you're back to sorting their candy... and worse. (kissing him on the cheek as she departs in her studio golf cart) I'm sorry, Viktor.
Viktor watches her depart down the canyon of stages, left alone on the deserted lot.

Twenty NICOLA ANDERS' FACES jiggle into frame.  VIKTOR's appears amongst them. They are cardboard figures, standing together in the trai of an electric cart.  A WORKMAN is collecting the promoti standees from around the lot. VIKTOR places his hands on the neck of a cardboard cut-ou we sense he is about to rip her head off -- when a fourte year old girl, LAINEY, appears beside him, carrying a lap computer.
Hi, Dad.
(slightly ashamed) Hello, sweetheart.
Viktor, embarrassed by his childishness, steps aside for suspicious workman who carries the standee away. Lainey smiles sweetly.  She hugs him.
I'm sorry Mom canned you.
(shrugging) It's really... not anything, Lainey.  It's just --
Don't feel too bad. (glancing to a standee) Mom runs the place and they still walk all over her.  You're better off out of it.
(regarding his daughter) You look very grown up.  What are you doing?  You meeting your mom for dinner?
She glances towards the entrance where Lainey's mother, ELAINE, and her dependable, uncomplicated businessman boyfriend, KENT, wait beside Elaine's car.
(reluctant admission) Kent got tickets to the ballet.
Viktor shakes the idea of Kent and Elaine from his head.
(trying to convince himself as much as Lainey) I'm going to finish the picture, sweetheart.  It's important.
(not quite convinced) I know you'll do it, Dad.  You're Viktor Taransky.
Lainey kisses the forlorn Viktor goodbye.  She runs to he mother and Kent.
(to himself) That's right.  I'm Viktor Taransky.
From a distance ELAINE and KENT regard the lonely figure VIKTOR.
You had no choice, Elaine.  He's a liability.
(wistful look to Viktor) He also happens to be the most talented man I've ever known.
Elaine climbs in the car as Lainey approaches.

CLOSE UP on a copy of "Variety".  The front page banner headline: "ANDERS RIDES OUT OF 'SUNSET' -- Cites Creative Differences" The man reading the trade paper sits in the back of a tra a studio tour -- HANK ALENO.  He wears a pair of spectacl with one lens blacked out, his head tilted on one side. is an item buried on the inside pages that catches Hank's good eye.
"OVER-PRICED, OVER-PAMPERED PRIMA DONNAS" - Director's Future Now In Doubt -
The tram pauses.  The TOUR GUIDE keeps up a commentary.
-- On your left, the house where Claris Commodore uttered those now immortal words, "If that door doesn't hold, stand behind me".  And coming up on your right --
When the tram departs, we discover that Hank has exited t tram and is hiding in the facade of a New York subway entrance.  The tag around his neck reads, "VISITOR -- Sta With The Tour".

VIKTOR wheels a stack of film cans on a dolly while holdi several framed black and white photographs of screen lege under his arm. HANK, hiding in the shadows of the soundstages, spies Vik He hurries towards him as Viktor approaches his antiquate Bentley.

-- Mr. Taransky, Mr. Taransky... thank God.  I've been trying to see you, calling -- Your assistant wouldn't put me through.  I told her it was a matter of life and death.  I was afraid I wouldn't get to you in time --
(using his stack of film cans as a barrier) -- Please, get away from me.
I did it, Mr. Taransky.  I licked skin.  I licked hair.  I licked every part of her.
(more disturbed, fearing he is dealing with a pervert) You want me to call Security?
I have her, Mr. Taransky.  The answer to your prayers. (producing the "Variety" article, conspiratorial) The answer to this.
(regarding the article) I was misquoted.
I have your new leading lady... (indicating the bulge in his pocket) ... right here in my pants.
Viktor takes a step back, concerned once again about the man's motives.

(trying to reassure) It's me, Mr. Taransky.  Don't you recognize me? -- The Future of Film conference in San Jose.  Hank... Hank Aleno.  I was keynote speaker.  You must remember my speech... "Who Needs Humans?"
(faint glimmer of recognition) That's right.  You were booed off the stage.  That's got to be -- ?
-- Eight years ago.  In that whole time, I never left my computer.
(wary) Good for you, Hank.
(referring to his covered eye) Good and bad.  They think that's what caused this.  Me eye tumor.  Microwaves from the screen.  It's the size of a grapefruit.  Heavy too.
(regarding the pathetic figure with the tilted head) I'm sorry.
Don't be.  It was worth it.
Hank once again indicated the bulge in his pocket.  Vikto now understands the significance of the gesture.
You have to see her.
(loading cans into the car) I've seen them all before.
Not like this --
(patronizing smile) Come on, Hank.  A synthespian, virtual actor -- ?
(irritated) -- We call them "vactors".
I need flesh and --
-- Flesh is weak.
-- a living, breathing actor -- I can't work with a fake.
Viktor loads his film cans into the car.

(pointing to Nicola in Variety) You already do.  But my actor won't get old, fat, lazy or drunk -- won't throw tantrums, demand a body double, script changes or a bigger trailer. (whispers, conspiratorial) The Disney Corporation has been using artificial actors for years.
That's the point, Hank.  No matter how good they are, they're still Mickey Mouse.  Everyone's tried.  Everyone's failed.  It can't be done.
It can -- with my new computer code, you and me, we can do it together.
I don't know anything about computers.
That's why you're so perfect.  You have something I don't have.
What's that?
An eye -- for performance.  You know the truth when you see it.  I know.  I've seen your movies.  I love your movies.
You do?
"Straw God" changed my life.
You saw that?
I've seen every frame of your work.  You're the only filmmaker in Hollywood with the artistic integrity to realize my vision.  You and me, art and science... we are the perfect marriage.
Listen, Hank, it's been a rough day. (climbing into his car) I'll call you about his next week.
(at the car window) I won't be here next week.  The tumor's inoperable.  I'll be dead.
(winding down the window) I'm already dead.
Viktor's car roars away.  He looks back at the forlorn Ha in the rear view mirror.
Call me. (looking at his watch) This week!
A huge eye from a dismantled Nicola Anders billboard is wheeled away behind him -- followed by a huge pair of lip
A sea of ingenue headshots.  Black X's are drawn through of them.  VIKTOR lies amongst the rejected faces, talking the telephone, in his spartan bachelor beach house.
(into phone, referring to a young woman's headshot) -- What do you mean she won't work with me?  She's done nothing.  She doesn't have a single credit --
(from phone, off-camera) -- Better no credits than a Taransky credit.  No young actress is going to step into Nicola Anders' shoes and risk ending her career before it's even started.
-- Art, you don't understand.  I've mortgaged everything to finish this film -- creditors calling, coming to the house, for God's sake, I need this --
The phone goes dead.  Viktor tries to re-dial -- disconnected.
-- Damn.
Sharp knock on his door.  Viktor peers through a curtain spies an official-looking MAN IN A SUIT, carrying what lo to be a legal notice in his hands. Viktor slips out of the back door.
VIKTOR hurries along the beach.  When he turns, he discov the MAN IN THE SUIT following him.  As Viktor runs, the S runs -- calling out to him.
Mr. Taransky, Mr. Taransky --
(calling back) I'm not him.
Viktor stumbles.  When he recovers, the Suit is on him.
Mr. Taransky, Sir, I represent the estate of Mr. Hank Aleno. (showing him Hank's obituary in the L.A.  Times) It was Mr. Aleno's last wish that you have this.
The Suit hands Viktor a heavily-sealed envelope.
What is it?
I have no idea, Sir.  He wanted you to have it.
The Suit departs.  Viktor hesitates, then breaks the seal the package -- inside he finds a hard-drive.  The hard-dr is labeled "SIMULATION ONE".

head_text.subj: A TITLE APPEARS ON THE SCREEN

text: a VACUUM CLEANER cleaning a tatty red carpet. On the other end of the vacuum cleaner is VIKTOR.  The re carpet leads to a rundown, downtown Los Angeles cinema -- venue for the premiere of "SUNRISE, SUNSET".  To save mon on posters, Viktor has altered the originals, "Starring NICOLA ANDERS" crudely pasted over with "Introducing SIMO
VIKTOR regards the sad, little premiere.  No paparazzi, n limos, no klieg lights.  Resorting to giving away tickets PASSERS-BY, Viktor approaches a HOMELESS MAN sleeping in trash.
Want to see a free movie?
(he thinks) No.
A taxi pulls up.  Viktor's daughter, LAINEY, steps out.
(kissing him hello) Hi, Dad.
Hello, Lainey.
Viktor goes to pay for the taxi but doesn't have quite en cash.  Lainey pays herself.
Your mother couldn't make it?
She's at the premiere of "A Cold Day In Hell".  But I think she send someone from Acquisitions.
She still with Kent?
This week anyhow.
VIKTOR escorts Lainey down the empty red carpet, regardin the pathetic premiere.  As they walk by, the bulb in Vikt sole spotlight expires.
Not quite how I imagined it --
(looking on the bright side) -- You finished the film on your own terms, that's what matters.  Did you really do all the post yourself?
There was no other way.
I missed you.  I wondered if you were ever coming back.
Me too.
(regarding the makeshift poster, trying to lift his spirits) Well, I can't wait to meet Simone... what's her last name?
You know, I... don't know.
Is she here tonight?
She can't watch herself.
They are interrupted by the THEATER OWNER.
-- Hey, we have to start.  I've got "Tough Love 2" playing at ten.
A foggy, empty pier.  A MAN is running through the mist, shouting desperately.
Valarie!  VALARIE!
Finally, out of the fog -- a young woman in a black cape hood, her back to us.  The camera pushes in, music swells she turns.  SIMONE.  She is exquisitely, ethereally beautiful.  Perfect.

In the near-empty, dilapidated theater, "SUNRISE, SUNSET" playing ON THE SCREEN. When Simone's face appears, the faces of the AUDIENCE MEM change.  They are all visibly moved, including the THEATE OWNER.  Some weeping, some with curious smiles on their faces, some opened-mouthed.
(ON SCREEN, approaching) Valarie, what are you running from?
(enigmatic smile) From Valarie.
Suddenly a GUNSHOT rings out.  Simone collapses to the ground.
(running to her) Valarie!  No!
VIKTOR, unable to watch, paces up and down, chain-smoking while worriedly shoving popcorn in his mouth.  Viktor fin musters the courage to look inside the auditorium.
The same scene that played in the studio screening room.  However now when we cut from the leading man, HAL, to the leading lady it is not NICOLA but the newly cast SIMONE.
-- Why are we here?  Is that what you're asking, Jack?... Why are we here?  No why.  Just here.

ON SCREEN SIMONE lies dying.  Now even LAINEY is affected Simone's performance.  She wipes a tear from her eye. VIKTOR watches the backs of the heads, trying to gauge th audience reaction.  Finally the credits roll. A dedication, "For HANK". No one moves from their seats.  Viktor permits himself a brief smile of satisfaction as he sees his name appear in credits: A Film By VIKTOR TARANSKY
Still no one moves from their seats.  Viktor cannot stand any longer.  He runs to the restroom.
Face over the stained sink, VIKTOR splashes himself with water.  He looks to the mirror, horrified by his own reflection.  He rehearses a courtroom speech.

Ladies and gentlemen of the jury, I may be guilty of a crime, but it was committed with the purest of intentions, to send a message to the acting community who put themselves above the work and above --
Three AUDIENCE MEMBERS enter the restroom.  They approach urinals.
(continuing their conversation from the lobby) -- So fake.
-- Totally artificial.
Viktor looks at the men aghast and hurriedly exits, missi the end of their conversation.
We're really supposed to believe that was 19th Century Lisbon?
Who's looking at the sets when she is on the screen?
All three nod in agreement and begin to urinate.
VIKTOR exits the restroom.  Almost all the AUDIENCE MEMBE including LAINEY, are waiting for him.
(pointing out her father) There he is.  That's my dad, Viktor Taransky.
Viktor is about to run for the exit when the small group spontaneously applauds.  They rush to shake his hand.
-- She is magnificent.
-- Absolutely unreal.
Viktor appears uncomfortable with their compliments.
She wasn't too... cartoony?
-- Who?  The nun?
-- Or are you talking about the mother?
-- A star like that, who cares about the supporting cast?
-- Congratulations again.  She was... not of this earth.  You should be very proud.
"Not of this earth".  A good way of putting it.  And the film as a whole -- ?
The group drifts away, leaving LAINEY and VIKTOR alone.
She's a miracle, Dad.  Where did you find her?
(vague) I saw her picture on the, er... internet. (interrogating his daughter's face) You really didn't notice anything -- unusual?
Only her brilliance.  To be honest, with what you had to work with, I was expecting a train wreck.  You really pulled it off.
Lainey regards the makeshift poster.
I have a feeling mom is going to take you back after this.
Viktor's head snaps around.  Lainey smiles.
Back on the lot.
Viktor shrugs off the misunderstanding.
VIKTOR enters his sterile, bachelor home, carrying his ma His answering machine blinks in the darkness, the message light reads "FULL".  He hits the "PLAY" button.
Viktor, you bastard!  I hear it's great. (beat) Seriously, I'm happy for you.
Viktor opens a drawer containing a photo of he and Elaine from happier times.  He gazes at it as he listens to the message.
I know people are going to be beating down your door but... well, I'd love the chance to buy back something I gave away for free.  Don't you just love Hollywood?... BEEP.

Viktor stops the machine, dazed.  He idly opens his mail. Inside an envelope he finds a SAG Card with the new membe name, "SIMONE". A MONTAGE OF SCENES BEGINS TO PLAY. A)  A line of AUDIENCE MEMBERS stretches outside the rund movie theater as far as the eye can see.
A dazzling new ingenue has come from seemingly nowhere to capture the hearts of movie-going audiences across the nation...
B)  THE FRONT PAGE OF "VARIETY" coming off the presses re "SIMONE: A REVELATION -- Dawning Of A New Star In "SUNRISE".
... in her debut film, "Sunrise, Sunset".
C)  A TEENAGE BOY in a public library logs on to the firs website dedicated to SIMONE.
Her face is already posted on everything from websites to bedroom walls.
D)  Trendy TEENAGE GIRLS saunter past a swimming pool in Simone capes and hoods despite the sweltering heat.
Her wardrobe has inspired a fashion craze.
E)  In a Third World back-alley a YOUNG ASIAN MAN shows a UNDERCOVER REPORTER a pirated recording of SIMONE on a camcorder.
And bootleg copies of her film are being sold in back alleys all over the world.
F)  A LIQUOR STORE CUSTOMER watches a TV behind the count showing a clip of SIMONE from, "SUNRISE, SUNSET Courtesy: Taransky Productions".

(from TV) But who is Simone?  We know so little about her.  No details of her background have been released, not even her age.  She is somewhere between a girl and a woman.  A fresh face and familiar both at the same time.
G)  The ENTERTAINMENT REPORTER now stands outside a multiplex.  The marquee has 16 screens and looks like this:
Is Simone even her real name?  And why the secrecy?  All we know for sure is that she was discovered by little-known director, Viktor Tarinsky.
VIKTOR, watching "SCENE" on a TV in the back of a limousi corrects the reporter.
Taransky.

(from the TV) He has parlayed his relationship with the new sensation into a three picture deal with the very studio that dumped him only six months ago.  And no wonder with the starlet's performance breaking all box office records.
Outside the studio entrance, a swarm of REPORTERS, PHOTOGRAPHERS and FANS rush VIKTOR's limousine, hoping fo glimpse of SIMONE.
Simone!  SIMONE!  I LOVE YOU!  I Want to BE you!
Studio SECURITY GUARDS hold them back as the limo enters lot.

ELAINE and an entourage of EXECUTIVES greets VIKTOR's limousine on the studio steps. A STUDIO PHOTOGRAPHER has a camera at the ready.  A banne reads, "Welcome SIMONE".  A YOUNG ASSISTANT wheels a cake VIKTOR steps out of the car.  ELAINE pushes past him, int the limo.
Simone!... Simone?
The car is empty.
(re-emerging from the car) Where is she?
Good to see you too, Elaine.
(ignoring his sarcasm) Why isn't she with you?
Why?  Because she would never show up at something like this.  She's intensely private.
Elaine sighs, exasperated.
(dismissing her colleagues) Back to work, everyone.  She's not here.
The reception committee disperses, murmurs of disappointm
Viktor... I want to thank you for convincing Simone to sign with the studio.
Don't thank me.  It was entirely Simone's decision.  Do you have Simone's check?

I don't have it on me.  Anyway, it means a lot. (quickly changing tack) Have you read the reviews?  They're love letters. (reading from a newspaper) Listen to this one.  "Simone has the voice of a young Jane Fonda, the body of Sophia Loren, the grace of, well, Grace Kelley, and the face of Audrey Hepburn combined with an angel".
(musing to himself) Almost right.
I can't wait to meet her.
I don't know if that's going to happen.
(confused) Why not?
As I say, she's... something of a recluse.  That's how she's able to stay so pure -- by isolating herself in her art.
(face falling) Don't be ridiculous.  I arranged a press conference.
Out of the question.  A circus like that?
Viktor, it's my studio.
She's my actor.  There are other studios, Elaine.  There's only one Simone. (leaving her on the steps) Leave the press conference to me.
Viktor strides up the studio steps.  Elaine stares after ex-husband -- she finds herself smiling at his newfound arrogance.
The studio soundstages as a backdrop, VIKTOR approaches a podium and a forest of microphones, revelling in his rece fame by association.
(tapping the microphone) Is this on?
Who are you?
Taransky, Viktor.  T-a-r-a-n-s-k-y, V-i-k-t-o-r.
Yeah, but -- who are you?
(patronizing smile) I am a two-time Academy Award nominated director with over eighteen films to my credit thus far including my latest release, "Sunrise, Sunset".  Who are you?
A REPORTER rolls her eyes at his pomposity.

I will not be taking any questions.  However I do have a statement to read on behalf of my leading lady, Simone. (reading from his statement) "To Whom It May Concern.  I'm deeply grateful for the extraordinary public response to Mr. Taransky's film.  At this time I will be conducting no interviews or making publicity appearances since I am really nothing without the beautiful worlds and characters Mr. Taransky creates for me.  I politely request that the press respect my privacy and let the work speak for itself.  All questions and inquiries should be directed to Mr. Taransky to whom I entrust all aspects of my career.  Yours very truly, Simone".
The reporters all call out at once.
-- Viktor, Viktor, who's Simone dating?
-- Viktor, where'd you find her?
-- Is Simone her real name?
-- What's she got to hide?
-- Is she the new Garbo?
-- Who's Garbo?
Viktor silences the reporters by theatrically raising his hands.

I thought I made it clear -- no questions regarding Simone. (bringing the press conference to a hasty conclusion) Now, I would like to close by announcing that Miss Simone begins production today on her next film, "Eternity Forever".  This project has been near and dear to my heart since I wrote it nine years ago. (a tinge of bitterness, then a smile) I Thank you.
Viktor exits the podium.  A voice stops him in his tracks
Who do you think you're fooling, Taransky?
Viktor turns.  The voice belongs to over-zealous, crusadi truth-seeking investigative reporter, MAX SAYER, accompan by his assistant, MILTON.
Do I know you?
Max Sayer -- National Echo.
(regaining his composure, a smirk) Don't you have a real story to write?  Why aren't you in Latin America?
This is the story.
I remember when the Echo had class  -- the paper that could bring down governments.
Our leaders aren't presidents anymore -- they're pop stars and screen idols.  If Woodward and Bernstein were alive today, they'd be right here in Hollywood with me.
They are alive, Sayer.
Milton confirms that Woodward and Bernstein are still liv

So they're probably here. (hardly missing a beat) You might be able to sell this 'disappearing act' to the rest of the world, but I'm not buying it.  What's really behind this Simone woman?  The public has a right to know.  Why is she staying out of sight?  And why the hell is she with you?  I don't want you to take this the wrong way, Viktor, but you're not exactly Cecil B.  DeMille -- more run-of-the-mill.
Maybe the reason she's with me is a little thing called integrity, Sayer.  Look it up.
Viktor walks away.
(calling after him) Oh, I know all about integrity.  I know even more about persistence.  Look that one up.
Max watches Viktor depart, with obvious suspicion.

A large satellite dish sits atop a soundstage. "CLOSED SET" is the sign on the door -- a surveillance ca panning the entrance.  A SECURITY GUARD, also keeping wat nods a greeting to VIKTOR as he pulls up in his studio go cart, script in hand.
No one came in or went out just like you said, Mr. Taransky.
Good.
Is Miss Simone coming today?

She's already here.  She arrived before you and she'll leave long after you've gone. (admonishing guard) Remember, under no circumstances are you or any other person to enter the set without my express permission.
What if it catches on fire?
Let it burn.  Simone would rather go up in flames than give up her privacy.
Viktor enters his secret code into the keypad lock and en the soundstage.

The cavernous soundstage is almost completely empty save a small table upon which sits two computer keyboards and tablet attached to a large, projection screen monitor and side monitors.  VIKTOR takes a seat in front of the monit
(to himself as he inserts his Hollywood hard-drive  -- SIMULATION ONE) Pay no attention to the man behind the computer.
A title appears on his computer screen. Welcome to
With a satisfied smile, Viktor backspaces characters unti revises the title to: Welcome to

He presses "ENTER" and a face begins to build -- wire upo wire, pixel upon pixel -- until a completed synthespian emerges -- SIMONE.  She is indistinguishable from a flesh blood actress. Simone moves on a video loop against a neutral background titled "VISUAL LOOP 6".  Within the confines of the monit she is reminiscent of a beautiful caged animal.  She look little bored as if she has been cooped up in cyberspace f too long.
(to the screen) Good morning, Simone.
Good morning, Mr. Taransky.
A star is...
... digitized.

Only now do we observe that Viktor is occasionally talkin into a microphone connected to the computer and pressing key on his keyboard.  When he speaks, she speaks.  Simone voice and mouth movements automatically sync in response Viktor's voice.  A scanning light on Viktor allows Simone mimic his movements.
You mean they buy it?
(nervous smile as he examines his first royalty check) Buy it?  They're paying for it.  And around here that's how you really know they buy it.
Viktor fondly touches a photograph of Hank that is taped the terminal -- from the "L.A. Times" obituaries.
I'm only sorry Hank isn't here to see this.
Viktor looks up, Simone mimicking his action.
(depressing the button every time he wants to express his thoughts through Simone) Maybe he can.
Do you have any idea what this means, Simone?  Our ability to manufacture fraud now exceeds our ability to detect it.
(appearing to indulge Viktor with a smile) I am the death of real.
(pondering the enormity of the hoax) You are birth of... what?  A Phenomenon.  A miracle.  A new era in show business.  All I wanted to do was finish the film.
And now look what you've started.  And now look what you've started.  And now look what you've started.
Viktor's conversation with himself is not merely for his amusement.  He is adjusting and refining Simone's voice.
Hmm... a little less Streep, a little more Bacall.

Viktor scrolls through a photo library of stars, living a dead, that comprise Simone. Viktor makes an adjustment on a panel on the computer scr dedicated to Simone's audio, incorporating the vocal deliveries -- "20% STREEP, 80% BACALL". He speaks once again as Simone to test the adjustment.  T voice patterns appear on his screen -- graphic representations of the sound waves.
Is that better, Mr. Taransky?
Yes.  Yes, it is.
VIKTOR snaps back to reality himself.  He scrolls through list of screen legends.  He clicks on the image of AUDREY HEPBURN.
While I think of it, I'd like you to add something to your repertoire -- remember that thing Hepburn does in "Breakfast At Tiffany's".
A clip of AUDREY HEPBURN in "Breakfast At Tiffany's" play the screen.  Hepburn, sitting on a fire escape, looks up.
(from the screen, an incomparable smile) Hi.
(pausing the moment) Let's hear you say "Hi" like Audrey.
With a CUT and PASTE, Viktor morphs the gesture seamlessl into a frozen Simone.  Viktor presses play.
(imitating Audrey's performance perfectly) Hi.
Perfect. (stretching) God, I'm so relaxed around you.
You did create me.
No.  I... just helped bring someone else's dream to life.
Mr. Taransky, we both know I was nothing without you.  I was computer code -- ones and zeros.

You're right.  You're right.  Of course, one doesn't want to boast.  It's a classic case of technology in search of an artist.  That's all you've been waiting for, an artist with integrity, with a vision, who can see.
Viktor gets up and starts walking around the room, warmin his theme.  SIMONE moves in a VISUAL LOOP on the monitor, nodding attentively as if she's really interested.

See beyond that irrational allegiance to flesh and blood. -- See that with the rise in price of a real actor and the fall in price of a fake, the scales have tipped in favor of the fake. (voice raising in excitement) -- See that if the performance is genuine, it doesn't matter if the actor is real.  Once a performance is committed to film, the blood and bones are gone anyway.  Only the spirit, the illusion remains.  Besides, what's real anymore?  These days most actors have digital work done to them so it's a gray area.
(Simone appears to look directly at her maker) Are you ever going to tell the truth about me, Mr. Taransky?
The only real truth is in the work.
You know what I'm talking about.

Yes.  Yes, I'm going to tell the truth about you, why wouldn't I...? (pondering his own question) Of course, with Hank's tragic passing, the secret died with him. (shaking the thought from his head) I am going to tell the truth... after your next picture.
Feeling uneasy at the prospect, Viktor changes the subjec He pulls out his script for "ETERNITY FOREVER".
Speaking of which -- this is the project I'd like you to do next.
Not, "Eternity Forever"?  The legendary unproduced script that was too good ever to get made?  I'd kill for that part.
I was hoping you'd say that.
Suddenly, Simone appears to talk on her own.
I'll do anything to please you, Mr. Taransky.
(pretending to be hard of hearing) I'm sorry, I didn't catch that.  What did you say?
I'll do anything to please you, Mr. Taransky.
On a side monitor, we discover a highlighted box marked " RECORD" -- Viktor's finger on the "PLAY" button.  He is unable to resist speaking another line.
And I will never, ever leave you.
Simone appears to indulge Viktor by blowing him a kiss -- until we see that Viktor has now highlighted a box marked

head_text.subj: FLUTTER OF EYES, FLICK OF HAIR, PUFF OF CHEST".

text: Viktor comes close to the monitor.  He notices something about Simone's face.
You're so beautiful.  Too beautiful.
Viktor accesses a program labeled, "DISTINGUISHING FEATUR He adds a "FRECKLE" and a "MOLE". From a distance we watch him, alone with Simone in the va empty soundstage.

VIKTOR's face against the SKY.  As he walks, we reveal th the sky is no more than a huge, painted backdrop on the studio lot -- behind a parking lot.  Viktor hands his val ticket to a fawning VALET MANAGER.
-- Just be a minute, Mr. Taransky.  We gave you a complimentary car wash -- they're washing the engine now.
Viktor joins other industry MOVERS and SHAKERS waiting fo their cars under an umbrella.  A young TALENT AGENT approaches.
Viktor!  Look, I'm sorry I didn't call you back last year.  I was, er... out of the country. (strained moment) But we should get together.  My schedule's wide open.
Sure, I'll... "call you".
The agent's face falls.  He gets in his car, disconsolate Suddenly, HAL SINCLAIR, rushes over and hugs Viktor.
Viktor, I'm so happy for us!
Hello, Hal.
The film.  The chemistry.  No reflections on Nicola but Simone and I -- we were just so right together.
You never were together, Hal.
And still the connection was undeniable. (aside) I haven't read "Eternity Forever" but I know it's brilliant.  And I know I would be perfect for Clive.
(correcting him) Clyde.
Yes, perfect. (lowering his voice) As a matter of fact, I ran into Simone on the lot the other day.
(genuinely startled) Really?  She didn't mention it.

(quickly covering) I'm sure she's meeting with a lot of people right now. (under his breath) She is just as you described her, Viktor... indescribable.  I strongly sensed she thought I was right for it.
Behind his back, Viktor surreptitiously presses a button his cell phone.  The phone rings.  Viktor feigns surprise answers.
(answering the phone he has just dialed, louder than necessary) Hello?... SIMONE!  How are you, sweetheart?
A hush descends over the executives.  Hal is suddenly ver uncomfortable.  Even the VALETS strain to eavesdrop on th conversation.
(winking to Hal) You'll never guess who I'm with... you ran into him on the lot.
It was more in passing.

You're so far off! (finally chuckles) Hal... Hal Sinclair... your co- star.  Remember now?... No, I don't think he's put on weight. (a shrug of apology to the appalled Hal) Anyway, you think he's right for "Eternity Forever"?... not the right type?... a different direction... (covering phone, to Hal) I'll try to talk her into it.
The other INDUSTRY PEOPLE make a note of the remark.  A mortified Hal excuses himself with a pathetic wave, climb into his car.

(into phone) ... Listen this is a bad place to talk... what?... sweetheart, I know you have charity work you want to do, I know you want to give back -- but remember, your greatest gift is your talent... we'll talk about it at the beach house this weekend... I'm looking forward to it too.
Viktor hangs up.  His car pulls up.  He tips extravagantl and drives away.  The INDUSTRY PEOPLE get on their cell phones.
Parked behind the sky facade is a curious CAR with shaded windows.
Inside the car, MAX SAYER and assistant MILTON, scanner i hand, are replaying Viktor's intercepted phone call on a computer.
(from the machine) -- "... You think he's right for "Eternity Forever"?... not the right type?... a different direction..."
(to Max, a shake of the head) I'm getting nothing from her side of the conversation.
Is it a jamming device?
(shrugs) Maybe he's talking to himself.
(dismissing the idea) Taransky isn't that good an actor.  No, they're taking special precautions.  Some kind of new encryption.
Why?
(musing) Whatever it is, it's dark.
Dark?
Yes, very.
They continue listening to the recording.
"... We'll talk about it at the beach house this weekend..."
MAX's eyes light up.  He gazes to a photo of SIMONE paste the inside of the car.
VIKTOR and LAINEY make breakfast.  Lainey is in her pajam occasionally glancing to a laptop computer as her father prepares French toast.
(glancing to the computer) Can't you stop that?
Why?
Those things can be dangerous.  Staring at a screen all day -- you miss what's going on outside in the real world.  You can lose yourself.  You should get out more.  How are you going to meet boys?
(shrugs coyly, getting up) I know plenty of boys.
Really?  Who?  Where do you meet them?  In a chat room?  How do you know he's not some middle-aged freak?
Dad, I can spot a middle-aged freak a mile away.
Okay.  But you have to find a way to escape that thing.
I do.
How?
I read.
You do?  Still?  I can't tell you how happy I am to hear that.
You were the one who insisted on it.  Reading me Dostoyevsky and Joyce when I was four.
You understood them.  That's what was amazing. (looking out the window) It's a nice day.  Let's eat outside.
Lainey grabs the plates and opens the deck door.  We hear chorus of CLICKS.
Actually, it may be nicer inside.
Viktor joins her at the doorway.
Stay here, I'll deal with this.
Unfazed, Lainey retreats into the house.

Boats are moored just off the beach packed dangerously fu of telephoto lens-toting PHOTOGRAPHERS.  The next door ho have LENSES protruding through the drapes of the windows. VIKTOR strides onto the lawn of his property that backs o the beach, soaking up the attention -- unable to resist waving extravagantly. Suddenly, a PHOTOGRAPHER, losing his balance, drops from nearby rooftop.  The photographer limps towards the fence Viktor calmly follows, retrieving the photographer's came and ripping out the film with a flourish -- he is clearly relishing the attention. The photographer clambers over the fence where he joins several dozen other SHUTTER-BUGS and VIDEORAZZI.
That wasn't her, Taransky.
Where is she?  You can't hide her forever.
(hurling the camera into the mob) You'll never find her.  Simone only appears when I want her to appear.
MAX SAYER from "The NATIONAL ECHO" is at the head of the accompanied by assistant MILTON.
She sounds like a prisoner, Taransky.  Are you holding her hostage?  Are you some kind of Svengali?

(recognizing the reporter) Who's the hostage, Sayer, her or you?  You look kind of "captive" yourself.  While you're spending every waking hour obsessing over Simone, guess what, I guarantee she doesn't even know you exist.  Get off my property or I'll call the cops.

The cops?  The cops read my column to know who to bust.  We're the only watchdog the public has. (looking around at the photographers) None of this is going away.  We'll be here tomorrow and the day after that.  Until you slip up.  And you will.  You are looking at your shadow. (getting in his face) Because all these elaborate precautions with Simone -- every instinct in my body tells me, it's not natural.
I'm just trying to help you, Sayer.  I don't want you to be disappointed.  It gets cold out here at night.
Nice try.  If we can't get to her through you, maybe your family will be more co-operative.  I can guarantee you, Taransky, one way or another, Miss Simone and I are going to get acquainted.
(turning away) I'd like to see that, Sayer.  Invite me.

VIKTOR drives along a twisty mountain road, LAINEY in the passenger seat.  They have become so blase about the paparazzi, they no longer acknowledge the posse of motorc PHOTOGRAPHERS risking their necks to stay up with the car
-- The rumor is, Simone is holed up in Taransky's Malibu home -- so far we haven't seen so much as a glimpse --
(switching off the radio) Honey, I'm really sorry about all this.  I don't know if it's safe for you to stay the weekends... just until things settle down.
(shrugs) Okay, Dad.
If anyone asks about Simone --
-- I know, I don't know anything.
Exactly. (slightly irritated by her lack of interest) Don't you wonder where I'm really hiding Simone?
(looking to him) I'm sure you'd tell me if you thought it was important.
Lainey gives her father a smile.  Through the car window behind her, a MOTORCYCLIST appears to lose control and dr down a bank.
VIKTOR'S car pulls up to Elaine's imposing mansion.  LAIN gives her father a kiss and departs.  ELAINE, in the gard overseeing a GARDENER pruning roses, approaches.
(from the car) Sorry I didn't get her back in time.
No problem. (she smiles) Do you want to come in?
(surprised -- pleasantly) Why not?
VIKTOR walks down a hall, passing the dining room, where is working on a computer.  Kent smiles blandly.
Hey, Vik.
(disappointed to see him) Hello -- Kent.

VIKTOR waits in an opulent drawing room.  Despite the eig degree temperature outside, a fire burns in the hearth.  ELAINE enters, waving a thick studio file.  Viktor's face falls, expecting a less business-related conversation.
Viktor, we simply have to talk about "Eternity..."
"Forever".
Whatever.  I still haven't received Simone's script notes.
There aren't any.  If the filmmakers are happy, Simone's happy.  She considers herself an... "instrument".
Really?  Oh, so she's really going to do all this nudity?
(shrugs) If it's on the page...
Elaine refers to her documents, bewildered.
Well, something has to be done about this budget.  It's completely unrealistic. (referring to a column in the budget) You allowed nothing for limousine service.
She'll drive herself.
Hair and make-up?
She'll do her own.  Theater training.
She was in the theater?  When?  Where?
I'll send you her resume.
Al least a contingency for wardrobe.  Any woman can go up a dress size.
-- I guarantee she won't gain an once.  She's very disciplined.
(concerned by an entry in the budget) Well, we have to do something about this -- "stuntwoman".
What about it?
There isn't one.
No need.  She does all her own stunts.
(skeptical) Even the fall from the plane?
(nonchalant) Even the fall from the plane.
Well, shoot it on the last day.
Viktor regards Elaine with a condescending look.

As I've tried to explain to you, Elaine.  Simone isn't like any other actress you've ever known.  She's about the work and only the work -- lives for the work.  She wants all the money up there... (gazing into space) ... on the screen where it belongs.  She'd work for scale except I know you only respect people you pay a fortune.
Which accounts for your percentage. (tossing the budget on the coffee table) When do I get to meet this dream?
Not today.  She's learning her lines. (glancing to Elaine's budget) You can also take cue cards and teleprompter out of the budget.
(smiles) I'll walk you out.
Elaine escorts Viktor out to the lavish garden.
ELAINE's demeanor softens.  She speaks to VIKTOR quietly, sympathetically.

Listen, Viktor... I want to talk to you now, not as Elaine, studio head, but Elaine, ex-wife. (correcting herself) Second ex-wife.  You got lucky this last time but you need to be careful.  We both know you wouldn't be making this overblown art film of you hadn't convinced Simone to be in it.
Elaine, talking to you now, not as Viktor, director, but Viktor, ex husband... what the hell happened to you?

(exasperated) Experience, Viktor.  I've seen this a hundred times -- young stars destroying the very people who discovered them.  I'm worried about you, that's all.  This woman -- she controls your destiny.
Simone does not control my destiny.
Viktor, I have a feeling.  One of my feelings.  There's something about her I don't trust.
From her bedroom window on the mansion's second floor, LA smiles at the sight of her mother and father together.
VIKTOR enters his office where he's greeted by his assist JANE.
(sheepish) Thanks for taking me back, Mr. Taransky.  I know it looked like I sided with the studio, but I always believed in you, honestly.
Don't worry.  I understand.
(referring to the cast seated around a conference table) They're all here.

VIKTOR sits at the head of the table, surrounded by HAL, LOTUS, MAC and three other CAST MEMBERS.  A preliminary poster behind him -- "COMING THIS SUMMER - SIMONE in ETER FOREVER" -- bears a huge photograph of Simone's face.

I can't tell you how delighted I am to have this wonderful cast assembled for "Eternity Forever".  Thank you all.  Now, a reminder -- as a condition for working on this film, you will not be rehearsing with Simone, shooting with Simone and you are forbidden from contacting Simone in any way at any time, whatsoever.
The CAST nods seriously.
(a thought occurs) How will you do our love scenes?
Body double.
(confused) For her?

For you. (addressing the entire cast) I want you to know, Simone appreciates you all working for scale.  But why am I thanking you?  Simone can thank you herself.  She insisted on speaking with you before filming begins.  She's on the line now.
Viktor nods to a speaker phone in the center of the table red blinking light on the phone.  The cast reacts excited
(pushing a button on the phone) Simone, are you there?
(through the speakerphone) I certainly am, Mr. Taransky.
(unable to contain her excitement) So are we, Simone!
Everyone laughs giddily.
Why don't you leave me alone with my co-stars, Mr. Taransky, so we can get to know each other better?
Good idea.
Of course.  I'll be back in a minute.
Viktor exits.
Hi.  Who's there?  Don't be shy.  Introduce yourselves.
The CAST stares nervously at the speakerphone.  Mac break the silence.
I'm Mac.  I turned down a Bertolucci film to be here.
My name's Lotus.  God, I can't believe I'm talking to you.  We're going to become such great friends.
I'm Hal.  Wonderful to be working together... again.
The other cast members introduce themselves.
VIKTOR pulls up sharply in his studio golf cart outside t nearby soundstage and hurriedly enters.
VIKTOR races across the vast, empty space to a digital player, connected to a phone.  Simone's pre-recorded open remarks (graphically represented on the screen) are almos completed.
Is that everyone...? (pause) Well, obviously, as you know...
Viktor jumps into the conversation in the nick of time, speaking through the synthesizer.  As usual, Viktor's voi is automatically synthesized into the voice of Simone.
... I'm Simone.
The other CAST MEMBERS laugh nervously.
(from Viktor's speakerphone) Obviously.  Who else?
(from speaker phone) I just want to start by apologizing for my "process" --
The CAST are hunched over the speakerphone.
-- No.  No.  I'm completely simpatico.  On my last film I was playing a schizophrenic so I made them give me two dressing rooms.
(an aside) So committed.
Well thank you for your understanding.  I know it's an unusual way to work but I just find I relate better to people when they're not actually there.
Of course, of course.
I don't have much to say except that I know it's going to be a great project, if we all just trust Mr. Taransky's vision.  Always do what Mr. Taransky says.  If in doubt, do it the Taransky way.
They all nod vigorously in agreement.
I know we're going to make a wonderful movie together.
(nodding in agreement) Wonderful movie.
Together, absolutely.
VIKTOR removes his own garbage from his soundstage.  A yo cleaning woman, VIVIAN, wheeling a janitor's cart, tentatively approaches.
Mr. Taransky...
(referring to the stage) No one goes in there.
Oh, I know.
Vivian hesitantly hands Viktor a publicity photo of SIMON
If it's not too much trouble.  Could you...?
Of course...

(hesitant about broaching the subject) This last year I was... going through some things. (shaking her head at the memory) Awful, awful... things.  But when I saw Simone in "Sunrise"... what she did... in the scene in the fireworks factory... (face lighting up) ... suddenly everything made sense.  My friends, family, doctors -- nobody could reach me -- but Simone, she really... spoke to me.
Viktor is touched by the heartfelt testimony.
She'll be happy to sign it.

A green set.  Walls, floor, ceiling -- all green.  A FULL CAST shoots HAL, dressed in a futuristic suit, tentativel crossing the green expanse. Hal pauses, looks longingly, then impulsively dashes forw Hal passionately embraces thin air and wrestles it to the ground.
Cut!  Cut!... Cut!
Hal freezes.  VIKTOR runs from behind the camera and confronts Hal on the green floor.
Hal, what are you doing?
Viktor, Clyde simply has to get close to Simone in this scene!  He has to touch her.  He has to!
Absolutely not!
But she's right there!  I must feel her!
You can't.
Why not?
(struggling to find an excuse) There's... a wall between you --
-- an emotional wall, I know.  That's why --
-- No.  No.  A real wall. (describing a wall with his hands within the green space) You ran right through it.
(confused) How did the wall get there?
I can't explain it to you now -- you'll see when it's all put together. (walking away) Anyway, we got it a couple of takes ago.  Let's move on.
Hal, dumbfounded, tentatively touches the non-existent wa
Viktor digitally adds SIMONE standing beside a sportscar HAL in a scene from "Eternity Forever".  He works on her close up.
(eyes welling with tears) -- What you don't understand, Clyde, is that love is like a wild flower, but that flower only grows --
Viktor hits STOP and Simone freezes.  Viktor brings up a and chooses from a range of "EMOTIONAL OPTIONS".

elated               melancholy           anxious jubilant             tearful              frightened giddy                weeping              petrified ecstatic             blubbering           loss of bladder inebriated           Kevorkian              control

reflective           chaste               seductive thoughtful           virtuous             lustful meditative           angelic              bestial stoic                Madonna              Madonna bored out of her      [Blessed Virgin]     [Like A Virgin skull He fine-tunes SIMONE's performance -- sliding a cursor on performance axis from "BROAD" to "SUBTLE".
Let's take it down a notch.
-- What you don't understand --
Simone freezes again.  Viktor make another adjustment.
I like it.  But still too big. (making a correction) Smaller teardrops next time.
Simone's tears retreat into her eyes.
It's not working.  It's not alive.  Let's try it again.
She repeats the line.  Viktor mimes the performance.
(teardrops arriving on cue) -- What you don't understand, Clyde, is that love is like a wild flower, but that flower only grows on the edge... (dramatic pause) ... of a very high cliff.
Simone FREEZES.
Perfect, Simone.
Viktor returns SIMONE to her neutral background.
I'm only sorry you still have to work with flesh and blood for the time being -- as user friendly as you are, even I can't manufacture an entire cast.

"To Vivian.  Love, Simone" -- VIKTOR writes on the public shot.  He applies lipstick and adds a kiss to the photo. Viktor wipes his mouth and looks to SIMONE on his screen she is waiting patiently, as usual.

We are going to have to change our plans, Simone -- you have no idea what an affect your performance is having on people.  We can't stop now.  There's too much to say -- these films they speak, they speak to the human condition.  We're changing lives.  No, revealing the truth now would be too cruel. (searching for more justification) Anyway, when you're seeking a greater truth -- in the work -- you are not so concerned with the lesser truths along the way.
Simone doesn't appear convinced.
You're going to get in a lot of trouble, Mr. Taransky.

(irritated at her pricking his conscience) Why do you have to bring that up?  There's always risk -- life's a risk.  It's worth it.  Besides, how could something so lovely be a crime? (regarding her tenderly) Well, I think we've done enough for today.  You've been cooped up in there too long.  How about you and me go out on the town?  They're expecting us.

He turns to a copy of "The Echo".  A photo of Viktor at t gate of his Malibu home.  "SIMONE HELD CAPTIVE - Self proclaimed Svengali Keeps Star Out Of Limelight".  Viktor puts Simone to sleep and picks up a briefcase.
VIKTOR, briefcase in hand, strides through the lobby of a opulent hotel.  He approached the CONCIERGE.
