He hits a button.  A thick WOOL COAT clicks over her body
The ECHO newscar streaks through the bronze and purple desert.  MAX and his assistant MILTON emerge from the car
-- I've been here before! -- On my honeymoon with my ex-wife.
Is that why she left you?
Max holds a video print of SIMONE giving her FRANK BRAND interview.  He compares her desert location to the one in front of him.
(pointing out a Joshua tree) You see, that's the exact same tree and in the distance, there's the... (voice trailing away) ... mountain.
Sure enough, the Joshua tree is identical but the mountai now obscured by a ten-story Holiday Inn. Max and Milton are mystified -- they look back at the pho
It's a hotel.
I don't understand.
Could they have built that hotel since yesterday?
Max shakes his head, deeply concerned.
Get in the car.

VIKTOR has transformed his soundstage into a one-man publicity machine.  The floor is littered with photograph SIMONE in various states of dress and undress. Using a sophisticated Photoshop computer program, VIKTOR constructs magazine spreads out of numerous previous maga spreads -- "Time", "People", "Us", "Life", "Popular Mechanics".
(angrily into phone) -- We don't do the photo shoot, you don't get the cover... written answers to written questions, that's right... website interviews, no problem.

Viktor calls up a "DANCE OPTION".  Choosing from a HULA DANCER, a BELLY DANCER and a CLASSICAL BALLERINA, he remo Simone's head and places it on the body of the ballerina. She begins to dance for him. He uses a program to construct childhood photographs of SIMONE and other childhood memorabilia. He employs backgrounds from numerous on-line library sour With a quick cut and paste he is able to place Simone on beach in San Tropez or a bicycle factory in Calcutta.
(muttering to himself) You want exposure, Elaine?  I'll give you over-exposure...
ELAINE watches TV in her office.  She cannot change chann without finding Simone sitting in a chair giving generic answers.
I think "Eternity Forever" is my finest work.
I'm most proud of my work in "Eternity Forever".
I think people are going to love "Eternity Forever".
VIKTOR inspects a cut-out photograph of Simone in "ETERNI FOREVER" costume.  He speaks to the photo.
Forgive me, Simone.
The photograph of Simone is emblazoned on a fast food dri cup -- a pyramid of cups promoting "ETERNITY FOREVER" Hap Meals.  Beneath the plastic pyramid is a SIMONE action fi in a convertible.

head_text.subj: "ETERNITY FOREVER" HAS BIG FUTURE AT B.O.

text: Screams the banner headline in "Variety". $$$IMONE - WINS 6TH WEEKEND IN A ROW
Shouts the "Hollywood Reporter". The trade papers sit on the coffee table in front of VIKT who reclines on a leather sofa, watching TV, gazing lovin at Simone.
Of course, being a movie star is wonderful, but I have so many other ways I want to express myself --
Various book titles are on display: "SIMONE'S FAVORITE SOUTHERN RECIPES" "HUMAN:KIND - The POETRY of SIMONE" "SIMONE'S 101 WAYS TO JOY"
A banner in a window reads.  "In Stock: SIMONE'S EASY-WEA FASHION".  Mannequins model the clothes.
We focus on the screen where VIKTOR types in instructions
A list of the Number 1 hits for the last forty years prom appears on the screen along with photographs of the artists --

head_text.subj: PATSY CLINE, ELLA FITZGERALD, ARETHA FRANKLIN, JANICE JOP

text: CAROL KING, WHITNEY HOUSTON, MADONNA, etc.  Beneath the t of each song is a graphic representation of the music -- "PITCH" and "RESONANCE". Viktor presses a button: "MORPH".  The audio waves conver

VIKTOR, wearing headphones, records his composite pop son As usual when he sings into his microphone, Simone also sings.  The catchy song is titled: "(If You Can't Believe Yourself) Believe In Me". SIMONE APPEARS IN A MUSIC VIDEO.

The video for SIMONE's song plays on the video wall insid the record store.  TEENAGE GIRLS, buying CD's, dance adoringly in front of the screen, unaware that they are gyrating to the vocals of a middle-aged man. INSERT - "(If You Can't Believe In Yourself) Believe In M shoots up the Billboard charts.

CLOSE UP on the name "SIMONE" painted on the stern of a luxury yacht. VIKTOR is at the helm, breathing in the clean air -- at l a moment to savor his success.  Simone's hit single plays the yacht's stereo.  He looks at peace.

A TOURIST has his arm around SIMONE, having his photograp taken.  However, we discover that the Simone is only a lifesize cardboard cutout used by a STREET VENDOR to sell snapshots.  He also has cardboard cutouts of the POPE and ELVIS. MAX SAYER and MILTON walk by. Tying up his boat, VIKTOR's mood is abruptly shattered by sight of Max and Milton walking down the pier towards him
Nice boat, Taransky.
It's a yacht.
I know what you're up to.
(pushing past Max) I don't have time for this, Sayer.
I think you do. (holding up his video print of Simone in the desert) I know it's a fake.
Viktor freezes.
Got your attention now?
Max compares the shot to one of the current desert locati with the Holiday Inn in front of the mountain.
(referring to the photographs) It's bogus.  You used an old library shot for the background.
(ashen) The background is.
She was never in New Mexico.  She never left the studio.
Viktor is relieved that Max is only accusing him of fakin the background.
(referring to a large bundle of other shots under his arm) I've done my homework.  I've studied her.
-- I bet you have.

-- I've looked at every piece of publicity she's ever done, the video in the supermarket, there's no evidence she's ever left the studio. (afterthought) Oh, and for some reason this woman leaves no paper trail.  But I have "obtained" a copy of your bank accounts.  I know you have power of attorney but so far you haven't transferred one single solitary cent to her.
I'm keeping it in trust.
I know that's what you'd like us to believe.  But I got to tell you -- embezzlement is a serious matter.  Not to mention abduction.
Abduction?
I don't buy the whole recluse scam.  How are you doing it?  What is it -- drugs?  Blackmail?  Mind-control?  All three?  What do you do -- keep her locked in a box somewhere?
Viktor flinches at the remark.
What is it exactly you want, Sayer?
I want to see her.  Unless you show me Simone live and in person I show these pictures to the authorities.
Viktor pauses, considering the threat.
Alright, Sayer, you've got a deal.
Er,... good.
That's good.
Viktor walks away leaving Max confused. The breeze whips the photos of SIMONE out of Max's hands into the sea.
A vast, empty stadium.  On the stage, a lone microphone.  VIKTOR approaches, gazing out at the vast arena.  Several PROMOTERS and TECHNICIANS join him.
All ready, Mr. Taransky.  This time tomorrow night, she'll be standing right here in front of a packed house.  We could have sold it out twenty times.
Viktor nods.
Soundcheck went perfect.  Laser show ready to go. (cautionary note) I gotta say, you ordered an awful lot of smoke.
That's the way she likes it.
The Promoter glancing to the area in front of the stage, where a barrier has been erected.
After what you told us about the death threats, the security guards are under strict instructions never to take their eyes off the crowd.
Excellent.
Viktor hands each man a headshot of SIMONE signed with a kiss.
Simone wanted you to have these.
(visibly moved by the gesture) Wish her luck from us.
Oh, I will. (afterthought) Remember, no cameras, no binoculars.

In the shadow of the enormous stadium sits a control truck/tour bus, satellite dishes on the roof -- the light from the laser-show inside the arena play off the truck. control truck shakes from the stomping of the crowd.
... SI-MONE!  SI-MONE!  SI-MONE!...
The door to the truck is marked, "SIMONE - Splendid Isola Tour.  NO ENTRY".
VIKTOR sits alone at the mixing panel of a control truck. his monitors, a sea of humanity, chanting.
... SI-MONE!  SI-MONE!  SI-MONE!...
Viktor produces the "SIMULATION ONE" hard-drive from his jacket pocket and inserts it into the computer. SIMONE appears on the monitor.
Let's get you into hair and make up.
Simone's hair rapidly grows in a number of styles, eyelas grow and are trimmed, eyeshadow of various shades paints across the lids.
Wardrobe.

Viktor tries several outfits on Simone -- the clothes appearing to fabricate themselves on her body.  He settle for the most provocative outfit. Finger poised over the keyboard, Viktor glances to a moni showing --
ELAINE and LAINEY amongst the crowd, clapping their hands stomping their feet and chanting.
Easier to make one hundred thousand believe than just one.
He scrolls to a program, marked "HOLOGRAM" and pushes the "ENTER" key.
Smoke fills the stage.  A strobe light show plays.  A boo ANNOUNCER is heard.
Ladies and gentlemen, Viktor Taransky Promotions is proud to present, live on stage, for the debut concert of the "Splendid Isolation" tour, the one, the only, SI-MONE!

A spotlight falls on the solitary figure of Simone, stand alone on the stage with a guitar over her shoulder (the o accompaniment) -- dwarfed by the huge stage.  However, on closer inspection, the spotlight is actually a laser beam creating a hologram.  Clouds of smoke and strobe lighting the illusion. The only clear view of Simone for the audience is provide the enormous video screens on either side of the stage. CROWD stares up at the jumbotrons, blissfully unaware tha they are watching a pre-recorded event.  Some watch the e on portable TVs.
CLOSE UP on the computer screen.  VIKTOR scrolls down a l of options -- "... HOUSTON, MIAMI, NEW YORK, L.A...."
(from on stage) I love you...
He selects "L.A.".
The crowd roars its approval.
It's great to be here.
SIMONE -- her voice a seamless blend of several DIVAS -- begins to sing her hit song, "(If You Can't Believe In Yourself) Believe In Me".  A verse of the song is sung in perfect Spanish.

A)  On a jumbotron in Tokyo SIMONE's concert plays LIVE. B)  On a TV set on a West African beach, children dance t SIMONE. C)  On a computer in a Bombay taxi, the driver and his passengers gyrate to SIMONE webcast.

VIKTOR's face is reflected in a monitor showing a frenzie crowd gazing up at the jumbotron -- singing along, many i tears, overcome with emotion -- holding cigarette lighter aloft.  For a moment Viktor is in awe of his own wizardry the grand illusionist.  Viktor is at the height of his powers.
(to the image of Simone on his screen) I don't know about you, Simone, but I've never felt more alive.
He snaps back to reality just in time to notice that the Simone hologram beam has wandered through her own microph stand.
Damn!
He adjusts the beam -- the rapturous crowd, transfixed by TV screen, apparently fails to notice.
We focus on a face in the crowd -- MAX SAYER.  His journalistic assignment temporarily forgotten, Max is sin along and waving his arms, tears rolling down his face, s up in the moment.
SIMONE finishes her final number.
Good-night.  Never stop believing.

A bin contains dozens of confiscated cameras and binocula FANS exit the stadium through a tunnel. S-I-M-O-N-E is spelt out on the bare chests of six TEENAG BOYS.  Other FANS wear "SIMONE - Splendid Isolation Tour" T-shirts and carry posters.  Several CONCERT GOERS speak TV NEWS CREW.
-- I swear, she looked right at me.
-- She was, like, ethereal.
-- One moment she seemed to walk right through her mike stand like it wasn't even there.

The chanting crowd can be heard exiting.  VIKTOR, wearing lipstick is hastily signing a pile of souvenir programs w Simone's signature kiss. He is interrupted by a knock at the door.  Viktor irritab opens it.
I said I didn't want to be interrupt --
ELAINE and LAINEY stand at the foot of the trailer, a SECURITY GUARD nearby.
(face brightening) My two favorite girls.
Lainey and I just wanted to congratulate...
Regarding Viktor closely, Elaine's smile evaporates.
... Simone.
She's lying down.  She's exhausted.
(suddenly cool) I can imagine.
Viktor is confused by their reaction.  Elaine yanks Laine away.
Thank Simone for the tickets.
(calling back as she is led away) It was a great show, Dad...
Viktor waves disconcertedly.
Where are you... going?
As he returns to the trailer, Viktor catches sight of his lipstick-smeared mouth in the mirror on the inside of the trailer door.  He slams the side of the trailer in frustration.
ELAINE paces back and forth in front of her TV showing re runs of the SIMONE concert.  KENT cannot take his eyes of the screen.
I can't believe she's doing this -- taking advantage of him this way.  It's cruel.
Why?
Obviously, this can't last.  She's going to dump him.  Viktor won't be able to take that.  He's too sensitive.  It'll destroy him.
Elaine, do you realize you can't stop talking about Viktor?
(not hearing) I have to talk to her.
Kent switches off the TV.
I've been meaning to talk to you.
Behind the open door, we find LAINEY eavesdropping.
VIKTOR, deep in thought, stands at the water's edge, star at the breaking waves.  LAINEY joins him.
Hey, Lainey. (gently teasing her) How's your love life?
I do okay.  How about you?
You know me -- married to my work.
I noticed.
An awkward silence.
Dad, you know I don't like to get between you and mom but she's feeling down right now.  She broke up with Kent.
(buoyed by the news) Really?  Too bad.
She thinks you're with Simone.
Lainey, you know Simone and I don't have a real relationship.
I know but Mom doesn't.  Maybe if it came from Simone, if Simone spoke to Mom -- she could straighten things out. (shrug) Dinner, maybe.
Dinner?  Dinner's difficult.  A phone call?
Too impersonal.  They have to meet face-to-face.
I'll see what I can do. (a thought occurs) You know, Lainey.  I don't believe you've ever once asked to meet Simone.  Don't you like her?
I love her but that doesn't mean I need to meet her.
Viktor is confused.

Why?  So I can tell my friends at school -- as if that validates my life somehow.  What's Simone going to say to a fourteen-year-old anyhow?  She's going to be polite because you're my father but we're not suddenly going to become friends -- we have nothing in common.  It's not going to be real.  Anyhow, she gets more beautiful in my head every day.  Why kill the dream?  What do they say, "don't get too close to your idols, they always disappoint you".
Viktor gazes in wonder at his daughter, so much wiser tha her years.
I love you, Lainey.
I love you too, daddy.
A car horn sounds outside the house.
That's Mom. (kissing him on the forehead) See you.
She exits, leaving Viktor deep in thought.

Milli Vanilli's "GIRL YOU KNOW IT'S TRUE" plays on a car radio.  ELAINE, wearing a red power suit, drives home alo the freeway in bumper-to-bumper traffic.  Her car phone rings.  She turns down the radio and picks up.
Hello?
Hello, is this Elaine?
Yes -- oh my, God.  Is that you, Simone?!  I've been wanting to talk to you.
Well, here I am. (beat) You look pretty today.  Red suits you.
(looking around the freeway) Where are you?
Right beside you.  I borrowed Viktor's car.
Elaine looks to the inside lane.  SIMONE, wearing sunglas phone to her ear, drives alongside.  Simone waves, somewh mechanically.  Elaine waves back.  They keep driving as t talk.

The sunglasses-clad SIMONE is a mannequin, seated in the driver's seat with her left hand on the phone obscuring h mouth, right hand attached to the steering wheel. Seat fully-reclined on the passenger side, VIKTOR drives car by stretching a foot across to the pedals and steerin with one hand, occasionally sneaking a glance to the road ahead.  He speaks on a phone through the Simone synthesiz
I'd love to stop somewhere but I'm late.  I'm on my way to see Viktor now.
No, I understand.  That's what I want to talk about.  I don't know if you know this, Simone, but Viktor and I were married once.
I can't imagine how you ever let a man like that go.  I owe Viktor everything.
I think he owes more to you.  But that's not important now.  I know what's going on between you two.
I want to reassure you, Elaine, there's absolutely nothing going on between Viktor and I.
(rueful smile) You don't have to protect my feelings, Simone.  I don't blame Viktor for falling in love with the most desirable woman in the world.
(breaking character) I'm not -- (correcting himself) He's not.
Viktor, losing concentration on his driving, drifts acros his lane, almost striking Elaine's car -- swerving back a the last second.
My God, are you alright, Simone?

Damn -- (struggling to stay in her/his lane) Yes -- I -- (regaining control) -- I'm just a little tired.  Listen, Elaine, Viktor and I -- it's strictly a working relationship.  We could never be anything else.  We're just so... different.
Exactly.  You're a household name now.  You're moving in entirely different worlds.  That's why I hope you're not toying with Viktor.
It sounds like you still have feelings for him.
We have a daughter together.  I just don't want to see Viktor get hurt.
I don't know how many times I have to say this, Elaine, but Viktor and I are not in love. (joking weakly) I only make love to the camera.
Simone, I recognize the shirt you're wearing.  I gave it to Viktor on his birthday.
Over-correcting his steering, Viktor drifts into the next lane, dangerously close to a pick-up truck that has to sw to avoid him.

Christ -- (still struggling to stay on the road) Elaine, I know how it looks but... (blurting it out) ... it would mean a lot to Viktor if you'd go with him to the Oscars.  If you won't do it for him, please do it for me.
(reluctant, frightened by Simone's erratic driving) Okay -- for you.
(sigh of relief) Thanks.  This is my exit so, I --
I'm glad we talked.
Good-bye.
Viktor's car swerves to the right.  Elaine looks back in rearview mirror, concerned. Elaine just misses the sight of VIKTOR's car rear-ending truck in front of him.
VIKTOR anxiously watches a HIGHWAY PATROLMAN writing up t fender-bender.  However, the Patrolman is more interested the Simone mannequin.
You don't have to explain.  I know what the press is like.  Lunatics.  Out of control. (referring to the Simone mannequin) You do know I'm going to have to take this?

VIKTOR, in his tuxedo, sits in the front row of the packe auditorium beside an empty seat -- "RESERVED for SIMONE". ELAINE and LAINEY sit alongside -- LOTUS and MAC nearby. HAL stands at the transparent plastic podium with the "Be Actress" envelope.
And the winner is...
Hal tears the envelope's seal, momentarily confused as he reads the name.
Actually, there's a tie.
The AUDIENCE gasps.
(milking the moment for all it's worth) The winners are... Simone for "Sunrise, Sunset"...
The audience cheers enthusiastically, but Hal stills thei applause.
(big smile) ... and Simone for "Eternity Forever".
The audience erupts.  Viktor accepts the congratulations those around him.
Unfortunately, Simone can't be with us tonight. (turning to the screen) But thanks to the miracle of modern technology she is able to join us live via satellite from the location of her new film.
The screen flickers to life.
SIMONE sits in a director's chair in the desolate wastela location chosen by Viktor.

Thank you!  Thank you!  This means so much to me.  I'm just sorry I can't be there with you. (wiping away a tear) First off I have to acknowledge my fellow nominees -- I don't even feel I belong in the best actress category let alone with these... wonderful human beings. (composing herself) I also have to thank my co-stars, the studio, of course.  But most of all, I have to thank the audience for supporting what I do -- you're the only reason I'm here.
The CROWD applauds wildly. LAINEY is puzzled.  She leans over to Viktor.
Why didn't she thank you?
(confused) She did... didn't she?
(crestfallen) No.
Viktor glances to the "Simone" sign beside him.  The bloo drains from his face.
On the monitor, SIMONE reads the forgotten line from the speech.
... And of course I must thank my collaborator, Viktor Taransky, without whom none of this would be possible.
VIKTOR, still in his tuxedo, stares at SIMONE on the scre He holds the text of Simone's acceptance speech in his ha
(to himself) It's written right there... Why didn't I say it?... How could I forget to say it?
Simone stares back at him blankly. A copy of VARIETY is slid under the soundstage door.  The front page headline, "NO THANK YOU - Simone Snubs Taransk Oscars".
VIKTOR pulls up to the gate of his Malibu home.  MAX is standing outside next to his car.
Damn it!
VIKTOR also spies an OLD WOMAN in a wheelchair sitting be the car, MILTON closeby.  Viktor stops at the gate and reluctantly exits his car.
What now, Sayer?
(smug smile, noticing Viktor noticing the woman) Looks familiar, doesn't she?  No one comes from nowhere, Taransky.  You turn over enough rocks...
The old woman appears drugged, stares into space.
I traced her to a nursing home.  A young woman fitting Simone's description dropped her off five years ago.
She looks a lot like you.
(undeterred) She hasn't uttered a word that whole time -- until she saw the big show.
Max produces a shot of SIMONE at the Oscars and holds it front of the old lady.
(pointing to Simone's picture, catatonic) My baby... My baby...

(putting his hand on his heart) Who would think that "Saint Simone" would abandon her own mother?  I've been looking into the family history -- heartbreaking.  Most likely a biography to run over four issues... who knows, maybe there's a Pulitzer in there somewhere.
Viktor produces his own driver's license and holds it in front of the old lady.
(pointing to Viktor's face on the driver's license) My baby... My baby...
Max hastily steps between Viktor and the Old Lady.
That doesn't prove a thing -- wait until I get a court order for a blood test.
(sensing an opportunity) That won't be necessary. (pretending to be resigned) Sooner or later I knew you'd crack this thing, Max.  You got me.
I do? (recovering) Sure I do. (taking Viktor aside) Can we speak off the record?  I'm a fair man.  I'm willing to sit down with her and tell her side of the story.
I wouldn't want you to compromise your ethics.
No.  Thanks.  Absolutely.
Viktor regards the newshound with a look of pity.
You love her, don't you, Max?
Don't you?
(writes a check, hands it to Max) This should take care of Mother.
Viktor drives into his home.  Max, very confused, stares the old lady.

VIKTOR escorts LAINEY, blindfolded, around the corner of soundstage.  He removes the blindfold.  From Lainey's poi of-view we see the sportscar Simone drove in "ETERNITY FOREVER" -- the car tied with a bow.
Happy birthday, Lainey.  Do you like it?
(taking in the car) It's fantastic -- it's too much.
It's the car she drove in "Eternity Forever".
I know.  Thank her for me.
(disappointed by her reaction) It's from both of us.  Of course you'll have to drive it around the lot until you get your permit --
Lainey averts her gaze.
-- I can't accept it.  I don't want a car, Dad.
(clearly hurt, not understanding) Why not?  I can get you something else.  What do you want?

The old Viktor Taransky. (finally blurting it out) I liked you better before -- before all this.  You were a loser, Dad, but at least you had integrity.  I can't stand to see you like this -- clinging to Simone's coattails -- it used to be about the work, and now it's all about her.  And then she's not even grateful enough to thank you.
No, that was me.
There you go again, blaming yourself.  Can't you see what she's done to you -- she's taking advantage, mocking you.  You deserve better than Simone. (hasty exit) I've got to go, Dad.
Lainey...
Viktor watches Lainey depart towards the studio gates.
VIKTOR leans on his desk, still reflecting on LAINEY's remarks.  JANE enters.
Ready for your casting session?
Viktor nods distractedly.  Jane shows in NICOLA ANDERS.
Nicola's here for the role of Simone's sister.
Viktor offers Nicola a seat, staring at her as if he has never truly looked at her before -- she has a quality of Simone.
(slightly uncomfortable by Viktor's scrutiny) A lot's happened since we last saw each other.
(numb) Yes.
I never apologized properly for what happened on "Sunrise".
She hands Viktor a peace offering -- a large jar of Mike Ike candy, including cherry.
Thank you.  It's not important.
After I saw what Simone did with the role -- you know I fired all my people, went into rehab, took acting classes, changed my whole look.  She really inspired me.
Viktor continues to stare.
(referring to the script in her hands) Would you like me to read?
Yes, I'd like that.
Nicola glances at the script a last time and puts it down She approaches Viktor, standing close to him, playing the scene to him -- an immediate intimacy.

(her angry words are in opposition to her amorous actions) -- Who do you think you are, Carlos -- coming in here like this?  With my husband sleeping in the next room.  Do you think I won't call out?  Do you think I will just give in to you without a fight -- like the last time and the time before that? (she kisses his ear) I wish you were dead. (she kisses his lips) I wish we were both dead.
Nicola immediately breaks character. Viktor is mesmerized -- he has fallen back in love with flesh.
(finally able to speak) You know you're really very good.  I take back what I said.  I mean, you're really good.
Thank you.
(forgetting himself) You could play the lead.
(confused) But that's Simone's part.
Yes, of course it is. (gazing at her face) You know you have a line here.  Not a wrinkle.  Actually, more of a dimple.  I've been thinking of incorporating something like that in Simone.
(incredulous) You'd cosmetically alter Simone to look like me?
No, of course not, you're right.  That would be crazy.
Viktor sits back down and stares out of the window.
Do you want me to do it again?
Viktor does not reply.  Nicola quietly leaves.

The front page of "Variety" is dominated by a large photograph of SIMONE giving her acceptance speech via satellite.  However, ELAINE is gazing at a small inset picture of VIKTOR, HERSELF and LAINEY arriving at the Osc Ceremony. Elaine tears out the photo and slips it into her purse.

Old home video of ELAINE.  She is in a garden by a swimmi pool, laughing, waving and sweetly flirting with the came Elaine raises her skirt teasingly, winks, gestures the ca operator towards her with a beckoning finger, finally blo kiss to the camera.

While the ever-seductive SIMONE waits patiently on-screen Viktor's instructions, VIKTOR is gazing at the smaller monitor -- the home video of ELAINE. Viktor freezes the tape.  Elaine appears particularly beautiful. Viktor electronically cuts out Elaine's mannerism and mor it into Simone.  Now Simone blows the kiss and has the sa dazzling smile.
At her desk, JANE is busy trying to mimic Simone's hairst as she talks on the phone.
(into phone) -- Oh sure, she comes in all the time... we've become close.  She told me --
VIKTOR enters the office.
Jane --
Jane hurriedly hangs up.
Gotta go.
(picking up a pile of scripts from the in-tray) I'm leaving early tonight.  If you need me I'll be at the beach house having dinner with a... certain someone.
Jane tries to conceal her interest.  As soon as Viktor ex the office, JANE picks up the phone.
(into phone, under her breath) ... Elaine Christian please.
We reveal VIKTOR, outside the door, eavesdropping on his assistant, pleased she has taken the bait.

VIKTOR dims the lights, plays "mood" music.  The doorbell rings. He checks himself in the mirror.  In the reflection, he s an autographed photo of HIMSELF with his arm around SIMON He hurriedly hides the photo and answers the door. ELAINE stands there.
Viktor, I'm picking up Lainey.
Elaine is over-dressed for her supposed errand.
Elaine, it's Wednesday.

(feigning absent mindedness) Is it Wednesday?  It's Wednesday.  How embarrassing.  I don't know what I was thinking.  With all the excitement lately... (peering past him) Am I interrupting something?  Are you expecting company?
(ushering her inside) As a matter-of-fact I am.
When is she coming over?
(glancing to his watch) About now.  Would you like a drink?
I suppose I could stay, just until she arrives.
Elaine takes a seat on the sofa.  Viktor hands her a glas wine and sits beside her -- close. They both knock back their wine in one long gulp, both apparently in need of courage.
(trying to make conversation) Is Simone back to earth yet?
Not quite.
I'm sure you'll keep her focussed.  She's lucky to have you, Viktor. (blurting out) Is she really having your baby?
Impossible.
(instantly regretting the remark) I just read somewhere --
I know.  I know.  They'll say anything.
-- And she was positively glowing at the awards. (making to leave) I should be going, she'll be here soon --
Viktor puts his finger to her lips to hush her.
-- She already is.  Simone's not coming over, Elaine.  Not tonight, not ever. (holding her) I want you back, Elaine.
(melting) I want you back too, Viktor.
They kiss.  Elaine breaks the kiss, suddenly consumed wit doubt.
This is crazy.  Who am I fooling?  I can't compete with Simone.  What woman can?
I would rather have you than Simone.  Believe me.

That's sweet, Viktor, but I couldn't let you do that -- make that kind of sacrifice. (meeting his gaze) It's strange.  I've stabbed people in the back, clawed and slept my way to where I am -- it goes with the territory -- but, for some reason, I can't betray Simone.  There's... I don't know any other way to say it -- there's a goodness to her.
No, there isn't.  There's nothing to her.
Oh, Viktor.  You say that now -- because we're here, alone, like this.  But in the morning, you'd go back to her.  What man wouldn't?
No, I will end my relationship with her -- totally.
But you don't understand.  She'll always be there -- at some party, on some magazine cover, some song on the radio, up on some screen.
(desperate) No.  She'll never work again -- retire, never make a movie or a record, or appear ever again.
(confused) Of course she will.  Her public will demand it.
Not if I don't let her.
You?
Viktor knocks back another glass of wine for courage.
I'm going to tell you a secret now, Elaine. (mustering all his nerve) Simone is not a real person.  I invented her.

(misinterpreting his remark) Every actor is an invention, Viktor.  Don't embarrass yourself.  No one's denying that you discovered Simone.  But it's like finding a diamond in the desert.  Anyone can trip over it, but it's not the finder who sparkles.
(agitated) -- No, no, I didn't trip over her.  You don't understand --

(ignoring him) -- You just got lucky that she's loyal enough to stay with you.  Maybe she's staying out of pity, who knows?  She certainly doesn't need you.  Some people even say you're holding her back.

(wounded) Who says that -- ? (shaking off the insult) -- Never mind.  You have to listen to me, Elaine.  Simone is thin air, pixels, molded by me from a mathematical equation.  I inherited it from a madman -- I can show you --
How much wine have you had?

-- She's a figment of my own imagination.  I, Viktor Taransky, have perpetrated the greatest hoax, the greatest sleight-of-hand, sleight-of-mouth, sleight-of- sleight in entertainment history! And still no one appreciates me, recognizes what I've done -- even you.
(rolling her eyes) You're drunker than I thought.  Are you doing that again?

No!  Whatever talent Simone has comes from me -- me!  Me!  I swear, as God is my judge.  You don't know what I've been through.  Tens of thousands of mind-numbing hours in front of that screen, nights without end, and look what it's cost me. (producing his spectacles) Why do you think I've been wearing these?  I may have done irreparable harm to my eyesight, and why?  To extract and refine the infinite nuances of a human being -- a human soul. (a final explanation) Don't you see?  I made Simone!
A pause.  His words hang in the air.
You made Simone? (a trace of pity) Viktor, she made you.
Elaine gets up and walks out, leaving the distraught Vikt alone in his house.
A hung-over VIKTOR enters his office.  Suddenly, he stops confronts the standee of SIMONE.
You bitch!  I'll destroy you!
JANE stares in shock.  She discreetly exits.
VIKTOR sits in front of his monitor, smiling venomously a SIMONE.  He begins to digitally disrobe Simone.

A)  Peering through a gap in the drapes of his Malibu hou VIKTOR watches MAX dig through his trash.  Max finds a beat up reel of 16mm film. MAX holds the end up to the light -- his eyes pop. B)  The ECHO headline screams, "SIMONE'S HARD CORE PAST" shows censored film frames of a naked Simone in a compromising position. VIKTOR, hovering at a supermarket check-out line, overhears two WOMEN discussing the article.
Disgusting...
(sympathetic) She must have been so desperate to do something like that, so depraved.
I'm still naming my baby after her.
You're having a boy.
So?

Viktor blanches.  It is not the reaction he'd hoped for. C)  Inside a theater, VIKTOR hovers by the door, smirking ON SCREEN, we hear a farmyard scene -- SIMONE in an empty farmyard on all fours, grunting like a pig, and foraging for muddy vegetables. The AUDIENCE is shocked, then suddenly breaks into spontaneous applause. Viktor, enraged, exits into the lobby past the poster for "I AM PIG - Starring Simone". D)  A pretentious FILM CRITIC talks to camera, a film pos behind him.
For Simone to do something as brave as "I AM PIG" at this point in her career, with so much to lose -- all I can say is, "I Am Pig, I Am Oscar".

E)  In his soundstage, VIKTOR moves a slider that adds wrinkles to Simone. F)  SIMONE appears on a morning talk show -- as usual, re on a TV screen.  However, her squeaky-clean image has gone -- hair unkempt, bloated, chain-smoking and drinking during the interview.  The HOSTS are smiling weakly.
Simone, that's a rather controversial position.
I just think all elementary schools should have a firing range -- so students can learn how to defend themselves.  We could fit it inbetween recess and American History.
Another clip:
If there's a hole in the ozone layer why can't I see it?
Another clip:
Immigration?!  God, isn't it crowded enough?!
Just as we always knew.  Simone's not like other celebrities.  She speaks her mind!

G)  VIKTOR driving along a city street, suddenly slams on brakes, almost causing an accident.  He stares numbly up at a twenty-foot high smiling photo of Simone on a billboard featuring a huge cover of TIME MAGAZINE.  It reads, "SIMONE: WOMAN OF THE YEAR".
(to himself) She's trying to kill me.
Realizing what he's said, a thought comes into his eyes.
An inscription on a headstone reads:
Remembered Virtually Forever
VIKTOR kneels at HANK's grave.  He places a bunch of flow there.

(referring to the flowers) They're plastic, Hank.  I know that's the way you'd want it. (glancing to a Simone billboard outside the cemetery wall) She killed you, Hank.  Now she's killing me.  She's a serial killer. (ducking out of sight of the billboard as if Simone is watching him) But I don't know how to stop her.  She's taken on a life of her own.  I can't just come clean -- make some confession.  I've defrauded millions -- they'd turn on me.  And I can't put the genie back in the bottle.  If she stopped working -- dropped out of sight, they'd never let it rest.  I've tried to kill her career but they like her even more. (more desperate) What am I going to do, Hank?
A thought occurs to Viktor.  He slowly rises from behind Hank's headstone, revealing a forest of headstones.
Don't say another word, Hank.  You are truly a genius.

A sad but resolute VIKTOR sits in front of his monitor, SIMONE's face full screen. He speaks into the voice synthesizer, Simone's face automatically speaking the words he speaks -- the final t he puts his words in her mouth.
What's the matter, Viktor?  You look so sad.  Don't you love me anymore?... It's over, isn't it?
He switches off the synthesizer and speaks in his own voi

It's the only way, Simone.  If it's any consolation, you're going to live on in the public's heart like all the other tragic figures that went before their time.  There's no love like posthumous love.
On the screen, Simone is on the verge of tears.

I know what you're thinking.  It's a phoney-baloney world.  The women are surgically enhanced, the athletes are on steroids, the singers are lip-syncing if they're even singing at all, the news is entertainment, the politicians are bought and paid for -- we're living one big lie.  So why shouldn't you live too?  You're more authentic than the people who adore you. (a trace of despair) And that's the problem.  You're looking at the real fraud.  I told myself this was all about the work but if that was the truth, it wouldn't matter to me -- and it does.  It wasn't that the artists had no respect for the art.  They had no respect for me.  Someone like you, you have so much love showered on you -- I just wanted to feel one tiny drop on my face.  I'm sorry, Simone.  Here I've been trying to convince the world that you exist, but I was really trying to convince them that I exist.  It's not that you aren't human, Simone, it's that I am.

Viktor produces a disc from his jacket marked, "PLAGUE - 8.1".  He places the disc in the machine. Viktor sees that Simone is crying.  He touches a tear on own face and realizes her tears are in response to his ow Viktor hesitates -- a moment of doubt -- then presses "ENTER".  The image of SIMONE's face gradually begins to deconstruct -- pixel by pixel -- as the virus takes hold. The pixels collect into a pile at the bottom of his scree like dust.  Finally, the dust is blown away in a single digital breath. For a moment his attention is taken with a layer of dust his own desk. Viktor regards his own reflection in the now black screen His hard-drive now corrupted, he picks up his original di marked, "SIMULATION ONE". He tosses this disc into a steamer trunk he has loaded wi hundreds of discs relating to Simone's software.  He shut the lid and begins dragging the trunk towards the door.

Viktor's yacht sits at anchor in the glassy waters of San Monica Bay -- "SIMONE" written on the stern. VIKTOR manhandles the trunk to the railing.  A mournful p -- then he heaves it over the side.  The trunk sinks like stone. Heart heavy, Viktor stares into the inky depths.
A throng of REPORTERS and CAMERA CREWS.  A somber VIKTOR enters and takes a seat in front of a forest of microphon
It is my sad and solemn duty to announce the tragic passing of Simone.
A gasp from the audience.  Then, an explosion of anguish.
No!!  What happened?!  Oh.  God.
(stepping forward, mustering the courage to ask the question) How did she die?
A rare virus. (pretending to compose himself) On her goodwill tour of the third world.
Did she suffer?
Mercifully, it was quick.
At the back of the room are MAX SAYER and MILTON.  They a frozen in grief, a tear spills from Max's eye.

A)  "SIMON GONE - FADE TO BLACK", reads the cover of Vari B)  The announcement of her death appears on local TV new shows around the globe. C)  A carpet of bouquets and notes of commiseration sever yards wide completely surrounds Viktor's property including the driveway.  VIKTOR insensitively drives over the bouquets to the horror of the MOURNERS, including MAX SAYER and MILTON. D)  In a remote Mongolian encampment MONGOL HORSEMEN crow around a television showing a live picture of Simone's funeral. E)  The HEARSE carrying Simone's "body" and the funeral procession led solemnly by VIKTOR, proceeds through the studio lot.  Distraught STUDIO STAFF toss flowers onto the hearse. F)  The same television picture is playing on a televisio sitting on a stool in a WEST AFRICAN river.  LOCAL WOMEN stop washing their clothes to watch.

We tilt up from Hank's headstone to an ornate mausoleum o island in a lake. Simone's coffin is ferried across a bridge by PALLBEARERS from the studio.  Numerous MOURNERS follow behind. VIKTOR, ELAINE and a curiously dry-eyed LAINEY walk behin the coffin.
(to Elaine) Can I see you later -- go away for the weekend?
(horrified by the suggestion) How can you bring that up at a time like this?

The coffin reaches the steps of the marble mausoleum.  A PRIEST, RABBI, and a BUDDHIST MONK turn to Viktor.  He no and they start to carry the coffin towards the door.  However, the coffin is suddenly stopped by a POLICE OFFIC A SECOND POLICE OFFICER begins to jimmy open the lid.  Th coffin lid is pulled back.  Inside is a life-sized cardbo standee of Simone from "ETERNITY FOREVER". The MOURNERS gasp.  Everyone looks to Viktor.
JANE sits in the interview room, describing Viktor's assa on the standee.
-- I heard him say, "Die bitch".
A)  MAX SAYER, distraught and weeping.
-- He was a controlling madman, she was a prisoner.  I blame myself... I should have done more to stop it...
B)  NICOLA gives a statement.
-- It was strange.  He wanted to replace her with me in his new movie... and I know I'm not that good.

VIKTOR sits in an interrogation room in a sea of SIMONE.  Magazine covers, cosmetics advertisements, publicity shot interviews, website print-outs, photographs and report ca from her fictitious childhood are plastered on the walls, stacks of film cans and tapes of her numerous movie and television appearances.

-- Forgive me, Mr. Taransky.  I'm just trying to understand.  All these films, TV appearances, magazine covers, internet interviews, publicity photos, snapshots from her childhood -- all fake. (referring to various items) This is fake, this is fake -- fake, fake, fake, all fake.
That's right.  You understand perfectly.  I will confess to fraud, not murder.
(referring to oversize mail bags) A fan club with a worldwide membership in the millions -- also bogus?
Oh, no.  The fan club is real.  But they were worshipping computer code -- ones and zeros.
So, of course, you couldn't kill Simone because there never was a Simone.
Of course.
And this Mr. Hank Aleno who you talk so much about, a renowned failure, who also happens to be so conveniently dead -- perhaps the "man" you claim helped invent Simone is an invention himself?
Viktor, sensing his sarcasm, does not reply.
(patronizing smile) But not everyone's imaginary, are they, Mr. Taransky?  I refer, of course, to Edith.
Who?
The Detective raises a window-blind to reveal a next door room where the OLD WOMAN from the rest home is being interviewed.
The woman you admitted to a journalist is Simone's mother and for whose silence you paid a fortune?  Is she not flesh to you -- are her tears not wet?
The OLD WOMAN glances up and sees all the photos of Simon through the window.
My BABY!
The Detective abruptly lowers the blind.  Viktor rolls hi eyes at the Detective's theatrics.  He is suddenly enrage

She's insane!  This whole thing is insane!  There is no Simone.  Look! (grabbing a Simone poster) Even her name is fake.  It's not Simone. (he tears Simone's name in half to demonstrate) It's SIM... ONE!  Simulation One!
The Detectives sadly shake their heads.
(regarding Simone's face also torn in half) You really hated her, didn't you?
The Detective places a tape, marked "EXHIBIT A" in a vide machine.
Perhaps you could explain this to me, Mr. Taransky -- or is this tape "doctored" too?
He plays a tape showing --
VIKTOR dragging his trunk from his car down the pier to h yacht.
It's footage from the marina's closed-circuit camera on the night in question.  Altered, of course.  Is that really what you expect us to believe, Mr. Taransky?
The Detective freezes the tape.
Can you tell us why you were disposing of the body of a woman who didn't exist?
It wasn't her body.  It was her body of work.
Why don't you just come clean, Viktor?  Tell the truth.  You'll feel better afterwards.
I am telling the truth.
(coming close to him) We all know what happened.  In a fit of jealous rage you killed Simone and dumped her body off a boat she bought for you.
No!!  I can prove it to you.  I'll take you to her.

VIKTOR sits handcuffed on a POLICE BOAT with the DETECTIV and his LAWYER.  DIVERS surface with the steamer trunk.  Viktor's face lights up. The trunk is winched aboard.  However, as it lowers onto deck, we see the latch has broken and the lid is ajar.  A eyes stare inside the trunk as the lid is lifted.  Apart a scrawny piece of kelp -- empty.
(panicky, desperately grabbing the divers) Did you find anything else -- drivers, discs... disc-drives?
Nothing. (gazing to the water) We couldn't stay down any longer.
All eyes follow the diver's gaze to several SHARK FINS in water.
"SIMONE"S BODY FEARED EATEN BY SHARKS"
The newspaper is being read by Viktor's LAWYER, sitting opposite Viktor in his cell.  VIKTOR is numb -- the likelihood of conviction slowly dawning on him.
-- Plead guilty and throw yourself on the mercy of the court.  It's the best deal you're going to get.
(incredulous) I could get the death penalty.
You certainly will if you go to trial -- a jury in this kind of ugly mood.  You've killed an icon, for God's sake.
I didn't kill anyone, Bernard, there was no one to kill!
(musing) An insanity defence.
A FIGURE sits at Viktor's computer.  LAINEY.  She scrolls through Viktor's files.  All empty. Lainey sighs.  ELAINE paces behind her.
Let's go, Lainey.  There's nothing here.
Just a minute.
Elaine continues to pace as Lainey works.
God, it's so like your father.  Why can't people take responsibility for their actions anymore?  I can almost forgive him for killing Simone -- but denying her existence.  I can never forgive that.
Because obviously she existed, right?
I know it as surely as you're sitting here, sweetheart.  She was the most vital woman I ever met.
So you did meet her?
Of course.  What are you suggesting?
I mean really meet her -- in the flesh.
Elaine regards her daughter curiously.

I know it's embarrassing to admit it, mom, but when I think about it  -- honestly, I haven't.  I mean, it feels like I have.  I know more about her than members of my own family.  She's even in my dreams.  But I realized, going back through my diary, they were all TV appearances, near misses at parties, second-hand rumor, gossip on the internet.  I've never actually seen Simone up close, touched her, been in her physical presence.  Have you?
(unable to refute it) Well, I --
-- We don't believe daddy because we don't want to believe we were taken in too.
(trying to shake the notion from her head) Lainey, there's no evidence that Simone isn't real.
Listen to what you're saying, mom.  Is there any evidence she is?
Lainey finally tries another file.  She presses "EJECT". "PLAGUE" disc spits out of the machine.
(regarding the disc) There's one part of dad's story that may have been true.  Simone may have contracted a virus.
Lainey smiles at her mother.
Certain viruses can be cured.
VIKTOR sits in his cell, arms crossed, quietly seething, while his LAWYER lays out his trial strategy.

(hushed tones, referring to a thick Psychiatric Report) ... Listen, I've found a psychiatrist in Ventura -- well respected -- who's willing to testify under oath that you have diminished capacity due to the trauma of your divorce, ten years of abject failure in the movie business and a bump on the head you sustained as a child --
VIKTOR, fuming throughout this, suddenly explodes.
-- No!  I can't go along with this horseshit!  Just tell them they can fry me!
(aghast, looking around to see if anyone has heard) What?!
It was premeditated -- I knew exactly what I was doing!  I strangled her!  I bludgeoned her!  I set her on fire!  I did it!  I killed her!
(clearing his throat) Excuse me.
The Lawyer spins around guiltily.  The Detective stands outside the cell, clearly overhearing the confession.  Viktor, resigned to his fate, couldn't care less.
I think you'd better see this.
The Detective switches on the TV set hanging outside the cell.  VBC is playing -- "BREAKING NEWS" --
A NEWS ANCHOR appears.
(from TV) -- Breaking news -- international media star, Simone, is alive and well.  Her studio released this footage only minutes ago...

The brief clip shows the front page of the L.A. Times -- headlines: "HOLLYWOOD SUSPENDS FILMING IN MEMORY OF SIMON and "D.A. Seeks Death Penalty for Taransky". The reader lowers the newspaper to reveal herself -- SIMO on the studio lot, looking more beautiful than ever.  She winks to the camera.
... Simone reading today's edition of the L.A. Times.  Who says, "The only bad publicity is your obituary"?  Details at the top of the hour.
The TV is switched off.  Viktor stares at the screen, try to take it in.
You're indestructible.
When he looks back to the Detective, he discovers him hol the cell door open.
(shaking his head in pity) I'll never get you Hollywood people.

A throng of REPORTERS, PAPARAZZI and ONLOOKERS parts like sea for VIKTOR, released from custody.  One placard reads "ASK JESUS TO SAVE YOU NOW".  He is escorted to a waiting limousine where he is met by ELAINE and LAINEY.  He hugs both.
VIKTOR sits beside ELAINE.  LAINEY sits opposite, studyin her laptop computer.  Outside the car, REPORTERS are pres against the glass.
(relaxing back into his seat) Thank you! (to Lainey) I don't know how you did it but thank you.
(putting her arm around him) Don't thank us too fast, Viktor.  You know what we have to do?
(resigned smile) Why stop at one character when you can have a whole cast?
Exactly.  Now that you have the studio behind you, we can really do things.
Viktor shrugs resignedly, savoring his freedom.
(holding Viktor close) I was thinking -- what about you and... "Simone" moving back in with me and Lainey?
(meeting her gaze) That sounds wonderful. (to Lainey) How do you feel about all this, Lainey?
(beaming) About you and mom?
(reluctant admission) Me and Simone.  What I did.
(sweet smile) Your mistake wasn't making something fake, daddy.  We're fine with fake -- as long as you don't lie about it.

Once again his daughter's words have a ghastly ring of tr Viktor stares out of the limo window as the car gradually forces its way through the reporters. He recognizes MAX and MILTON amongst the mob.  Max has hastily scribbled a note that he presses against the window -- "WILL PAY $ FOR EXCLUSIVE".  Viktor looks away.
(kissing him on the cheek) Don't look so glum, Viktor.  It's not a death sentence.
(still staring out of the window, a rueful smile) No... it's life.
FRANK BRAND conducts a remote interview with SIMONE who appears as usual on a television monitor.
-- Simone, the question on everyone's mind is simply... "why?"
Frank, you know as well as I do, living in a fish bowl, the insatiable appetite of the media...
Frank nods sympathetically.
With everything that was going on in my life, I just needed to drop out of sight for a while -- I needed time.  Viktor bought me that time.  I owe him so much.
We all do. (quickly returning to Simone) But now I understand you're eager to get back to work -- and not the kind of work that we're all expecting.
(smiles coyly) That's true.  I can reveal that I am considering a career in politics.
And what may I ask brought this on?
SIMONE holds up a beautiful BABY BOY to camera.

I suppose this little man had something to do with it.  Viktor and I are both concerned about what kind of world our new son, Chip, is going to grow up in. (turning lovingly to Viktor) Aren't you, Viktor?
On Frank Brand's monitor, the camera pulls back to reveal VIKTOR, sitting on a sofa -- an idyllic domestic scene.
(turning lovingly to Simone) Yes.
Only we see the set where the interview is being recorded VIKTOR is sitting on a sofa against a green screen in his soundstage, smiling at a woman and child who are not ther he is alone.
